entry.title: Re: Request to process an invisible SAP for Me Service Re...
entry.content:
The reason why you are unable to raise request "Set Up Hyperscaler AWS Transit Gateway" is because you don't have the necessary authorization to do so. After conducting research on S-user ID S00xxxxxxxx, it was discovered that your S-user is currently only assigned the Create Billable Service Requests permission at the installation level, and not at the customer number level.

To obtain the necessary authorization, it is advisable to utilize the Self-Service Request option (KBA 2891528) or reach out to your Super Administrator directly as indicated in Users & Contacts - SAP for Me.

For more detailed information on S-user authorizations required the Private Cloud Service Request application, please refer to KBA 2669783 - S-user authorizations required for the Private Cloud Service Request application - SAP for Me 

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Converting a Smart Filter into a Smart MultiComboBox in SAPUI5
entry.content:
Introduction

Sometimes a regular Smart Filter isnâ€™t enough ,especially when the field values are case-sensitive.
By switching to a Smart MultiComboBox filter, we can let users pick multiple exact matches from a predefined list, avoiding case-related headaches and making filtering faster.

 

Prerequisites

  • A CAPM entity your Smart Table is bound to.
  • A group-by view  or entity that will return distinct values for your filter field.

 

Step 1: Understanding the current filter setup

Right now, your Smart Filter Bar probably has a multi-value token input for status.
Weâ€™re going to replace that with a MultiComboBox so users can simply tick the statuses they want, without worrying about typing the exact case.

 

Step 2: Create the dropdown source entity

Hereâ€™s an example CDS view to provide unique status values:

entity StatusDropDown as

    select from mlc.Employees {
      key status
    } group by status;
  • key status â†’ Marks status as the unique identifier in the list.
  • group by status â†’ Ensures we only get distinct statuses (case-sensitive).
  • This becomes the data source for the MultiComboBox items.

Step 3: Add XML namespaces

Make sure your XML file includes:

xmlns:smartfilterbar="sap.ui.comp.smartfilterbar"

xmlns:smartField="sap.ui.comp.smartfield"

xmlns:core="sap.ui.core"

Step 4: Replace smart filter with a Smart MultiComboBox

<smartfilterbar:ControlConfiguration

    key="status"

    index="30"

    label="Status"

    visibleInAdvancedArea="true"

    filterType="searchExpression"

    groupId="_BASIC">

   

    <smartfilterbar:customControl>

        <MultiComboBox

            id="StatusDropDown"

            items="{path: '/StatusDropDown', sorter: {path: 'status'}}">

            <items>

                <core:Item key="{status}" text="{status}" />

            </items>

        </MultiComboBox>

    </smartfilterbar:customControl>

</smartfilterbar:ControlConfiguration>
  • We bind the MultiComboBox to the /StatusDropDown entity.
  • The status field is both the key and display text.
  • Sorting ensures the list looks organized.

 

Step 5: Hook into beforeRebindTable

Add this in your Smart Table XML:

beforeRebindTable="onBeforeRebindTable"

Step 6: Import libraries in your controller

"sap/ui/model/Filter",
"sap/ui/model/FilterOperator",

 

Step 7: Filtering logic for multiple selections

onBeforeRebindTable: function (oEvent) {

    const oBindingParams = oEvent.getParameter("bindingParams");

    const aStatus = this.getView().byId("StatusDropDown").getSelectedKeys();

    if (aStatus && aStatus.length > 0) {
        const orFilters = aStatus.map(status =>
            new Filter("status", FilterOperator.EQ, status)
        );

        oBindingParams.filters.push(
            new Filter({ filters: orFilters, and: false }) // OR logic
        );

    }

}

Step 8: Test it out

Reload the app, open the filter bar, and you should see your MultiComboBox instead of the regular filter.
Pick a few statuses  and the table should only show matching records.

 

Conclusion

By converting a multi-value Smart Filter into a Smart MultiComboBox, we:

  • Gave users the flexibility to select multiple exact matches without typing.
  • Avoided case-sensitivity issues by letting the system pull valid values directly from the backend.
  • Made the filtering process faster and more reliable for real-world datasets where values like Active, active, and ACTIVE might all exist.

This approach is clean, reusable, and works seamlessly with Smart Table + Smart Filter Bar setups in SAPUI5.

entry.title: Re: Error: configuring Flexible Workflow item to return t...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) answers your question?

Error Activating Workflow for Purchasing Contract

It seems you are encountering an error related to the agent rule â€˜/RULE/WF_INITIATORâ€™ not being defined in the scenario for the step â€˜ReworkCTRâ€™. This error typically occurs when the workflow configuration is missing necessary definitions or conditions.

Steps to Resolve:

  1. Check Agent Rule Definition: Ensure that the agent rule â€˜/RULE/WF_INITIATORâ€™ is properly defined in your workflow scenario. You might need to access the app â€˜Manage Workflows for Purchase Contractsâ€™ How to Configure the Flexible Workflow for Purchase Contracts and verify the agent determination rules. Workflow Features for Purchase Contracts

  2. Scenario Activation: Make sure that the scenario is activated correctly. You can do this by navigating to the configuration environment and checking the activation status of the workflow scenario.

  3. Custom Logic: If you are using custom logic for agent determination, ensure that the implementation is correct and published. You can use the â€˜Custom Logicâ€™ app to verify and update your BAdI implementations.

  4. SAP Notes: Although you mentioned SAP Note 3372372, it might not be applicable for your situation. However, you can check for any relevant SAP Notes that might address similar issues in the SAP Public Cloud environment.

Source Documents
[1] How to Configure the Flexible Workflow for Purchase Contracts
[2] Workflow Features for Purchase Contracts
Kind regards, Henrike

entry.title: SAP Successfactors compensation - control compensation eligibility via MDF
entry.content:
Introduction:

This blog helps to do config steps required to in SAP SF Compensation, you can govern employee eligibility through custom MDF and business rules.

  • Creating a MDF object,

  • Designing business rules,

  • Associating those rules with the compensation templates.

Scenario: There would be a  requirement based on MDF object, writing a business rule for the eligibility in Successfactors Compensation. 

Create a Custom MDF Object:

  • We need to create a custom MDF object that will store the eligibility criteria for your compensation plan template. 
  • For example, create an object based on to track performance ratings, bonus eligibility, or other factors relevant to compensation. 

Define Eligibility Rules:

  • Use the MDF Business Rule Engine to create eligibility rules based on the custom MDF object. Use the base object as Employment Details
  • These rules will determine which employees are eligible for compensation based on the data stored in the MDF object. 

 

If you have a field in Employee Central or a MDF Table which will determine eligibility you can set the eligibility in the Design Worksheet.

    1. From the template, navigate to Plan Setup; Design Worksheet; Design Worksheet
    2. From the drop down that defaults to Form Fields choose Eligibility Fields
    3. Click Add Eligibility Column
    4. Choose Compensation and Salary (Tab) and Click Done
    5. For Each field, map the eligibility to the correct field in EC or on the MDF

Map Eligibility Rule to Compensation Plan:

  • Map the Business rule to your compensation plan template under plan details, Eligibility

Apply the rule, then based on MDF the eligible employee will appear in the worksheet accordingly.

Conclusion:

By creating a custom MDF object, defining business rules with the MDF Business Rules Engine, and then mapping these rules to your compensation plan, you can build a flexible  eligibility in SAP SuccessFactors

entry.title: Singleton Entities in RAP Design, Multi Line Edit, and Best Practices
entry.content:
In  this blog I have explained creating of an RAP Singleton entity  with multiline edit  functionalities , and also coevered below topics 
1.copy action

2. Depricate actions

3.invalidating entries

4.transport organizer 

  • Add Copy Action : Helps to create new entries in object page 

In case we have  lot of fields and we  need to refer existing entries --> and based on that if we want to create new entries we can make use of this action 

  • Add Deprecate Action :  If we want to deprecate some entries ( make it invalid )  

We can make use of this action  

Select to include a deprecate and invalidate action in the generated app 

Pre requisite : the table must have  a field CONFIGDEPRECATIONCODE with data element CONFIG_DEPRECATION_CODE  

  • Data Consistency Check : select this option to include a validation for the prepare draft action in the generated app which checks the consistency  of the input fields with  

Domain with fixed values 

Foreign keys where @abapCatalog.foreign key.screenCheck : true 

 If we have foreign key relationship / data element / domain 

( suppose we have gender field in the employee table --> we need to maintain it in the 

Domain level ) 

We can make use of  this field. 


<< 

Enable Transport Selection selected  

  • The transport request selection action displayed in edit mode 
  • The transport request information is displayed in the header toolbar 
  • If the save action is executed without  selected transport request and the transport is mandatory , the action to select a transport request is triggered automatically . 
  • After  selecting  a transport request , the save action continues  

 

If the action is not selected , a transport selection is made possible using an action button . This option is selected by default    

 

< Manual :   

 Select manual to include the action select transport  in the generated app 

With this action , you can select an existing customizing transport request before saving the configuration changes  

< Manual with pre selection  

To include the action select transport in the generated app .  

With this action , you can select an existing customizing transport request before saving the configuration changes. When the edit action is performed , a customizing transport request is determined automatically 

< No transport : Select No transport for an app without a transport suitable  fro configurations that are to be adjusted in the productive system 

 

 T1. take a custom table say employee 

@EndUserText.label : 'employee table' 
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE 
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT 
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #C 
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED 
define table zpd_dt_em { 

key client : abap.clnt not null; 
key employee_id : zpd_de_emp not null; 
@EndUserText.label : 'First Name' 
first_name : abap.char(50); 
@EndUserText.label : 'Last Name' 
last_name : abap.char(50); 
@EndUserText.label : 'Department' 
department : abap.char(20); 
@EndUserText.label : 'Joining Date' 
joining_date : abap.dats; 
@EndUserText.label : 'Active Employee' 
is_active : abap.char(1); 
@EndUserText.label : 'Changed By' 
changed_by : abap.char(12); 
configdeprecationcode : config_deprecation_code; 
local_last_changed_at : abp_locinst_lastchange_tstmpl; 
changed_at : abp_lastchange_tstmpl; 

}

2. Create a LANGUAGE TABLE : 

Here we need one  entry â€“ so we have selected I_Language and put into the  

Where condition so that we get one entry to achieve singleton  

3.  select table and click on select generate repository objects

4. 

5.Delivery class must be C 

6. Data maintenance should be allowed

7.Also we need to have a data element( domain )

8. Provide package

9. We have business service definition and binding 

10. 

.Also, we have singleton entity details 

  • Singleton entity name ( EmployeeTableAll) 
  • Interface view ( Zi_EmployeeTable_S) 
  • Projection view  ( Zi_EmployeeTable_S) 
  • Key field (SinlgetonID) 
  • Draft table (zpd_dt_empl_d_s) 

11. Table details 

12. we can be able to see the classes 

 

13. we have scenario option 

 

 

 

14 Transport selection : 

 

 

15. activate the service binding

16. All the atrifacts will be generated 

intreface view:

@EndUserText.label: 'employee table' 
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #MANDATORY 
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true 

define view entity ZI_EmployeeTable1 
as select from ZPD_DT_EM 
association to parent ZI_EmployeeTable_S1 as _EmployeeTableAll on $projection.SingletonID = _EmployeeTableAll.SingletonID 
association [0..*] to I_ConfignDeprecationCodeText as _ConfignDeprecationCodeText on $projection.ConfigDeprecationCode = _ConfignDeprecationCodeText.ConfigurationDeprecationCode 

{ 

key EMPLOYEE_ID as EmployeeId, 
FIRST_NAME as FirstName, 
LAST_NAME as LastName, 
DEPARTMENT as Department, 
JOINING_DATE as JoiningDate, 
IS_ACTIVE as IsActive, 
CHANGED_BY as ChangedBy, 
@ObjectModel.text.association: '_ConfignDeprecationCodeText' 
@Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [ { 

entity: { 

name: 'I_ConfignDeprecationCode', 
element: 'ConfigurationDeprecationCode' 

} 

} ] 

CONFIGDEPRECATIONCODE as ConfigDeprecationCode, 
@Semantics.systemDateTime.localInstanceLastChangedAt: true 
@Consumption.hidden: true 
LOCAL_LAST_CHANGED_AT as LocalLastChangedAt, 
@Semantics.systemDateTime.lastChangedAt: true 
CHANGED_AT as ChangedAt, 
@Consumption.hidden: true 
1 as SingletonID, 
_EmployeeTableAll, 
case when CONFIGDEPRECATIONCODE = 'W' then 2 when CONFIGDEPRECATIONCODE = 'E' then 1 else 3 end as ConfigDeprecationCode_Critlty, 
_ConfignDeprecationCodeText 

}

17.

parent entity for interface  

Here we have made joined I_language  with employee table because  

We want Etag field from the table so that we can get lastchangedat field 

<< one more association is created related to transport â€“ because we need to capture the entries in transport ( I_abap_transportrequesttext) 

@EndUserText.label: 'employee table Singleton' 
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED 
@ObjectModel.semanticKey: [ 'SingletonID' ] 
@UI: { 

headerInfo: { 
typeName: 'EmployeeTableAll' 

} 

} 

define root view entity ZI_EmployeeTable_S1 

as select from I_Language 
left outer join ZPD_DT_EM on 0 = 0 
association [0..*] to I_ABAPTransportRequestText as _ABAPTransportRequestText on $projection.TransportRequestID = _ABAPTransportRequestText.TransportRequestID 
composition [0..*] of ZI_EmployeeTable1 as _EmployeeTable 

{ 

@UI.facet: [ { 

id: 'ZI_EmployeeTable1',  
purpose: #STANDARD,  
type: #LINEITEM_REFERENCE,  
label: 'employee table',  
position: 1 ,  
targetElement: '_EmployeeTable' 

} ] 

@UI.lineItem: [ { 
position: 1  

} ] 

key 1 as SingletonID, 
_EmployeeTable, 
@UI.hidden: true 
max( ZPD_DT_EM.CHANGED_AT ) as LastChangedAtMax, 
@ObjectModel.text.association: '_ABAPTransportRequestText' 
@UI.identification: [ { 

position: 2 ,  
type: #WITH_INTENT_BASED_NAVIGATION,  
semanticObjectAction: 'manage' 

} ] 

@Consumption.semanticObject: 'CustomizingTransport' 
cast( '' as SXCO_TRANSPORT) as TransportRequestID, 
_ABAPTransportRequestText 

} 

where I_Language.Language = $session.system_language

18. child entity holds the singleton filed including  all other fields

@EndUserText.label: 'employee table' 
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #MANDATORY 
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true 
define view entity ZI_EmployeeTable1 

as select from ZPD_DT_EM 
association to parent ZI_EmployeeTable_S1 as _EmployeeTableAll on $projection.SingletonID = _EmployeeTableAll.SingletonID 
association [0..*] to I_ConfignDeprecationCodeText as _ConfignDeprecationCodeText on $projection.ConfigDeprecationCode = _ConfignDeprecationCodeText.ConfigurationDeprecationCode 

{ 

key EMPLOYEE_ID as EmployeeId, 
FIRST_NAME as FirstName, 
LAST_NAME as LastName, 
DEPARTMENT as Department,

IS_ACTIVE as IsActive, 
CHANGED_BY as ChangedBy, 
@ObjectModel.text.association: '_ConfignDeprecationCodeText' 
@Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [ { 

entity: { 
name: 'I_ConfignDeprecationCode',  
element: 'ConfigurationDeprecationCode' 

} 

} ] 

CONFIGDEPRECATIONCODE as ConfigDeprecationCode, 
@Semantics.systemDateTime.localInstanceLastChangedAt: true 
@Consumption.hidden: true 
LOCAL_LAST_CHANGED_AT as LocalLastChangedAt, 
@Semantics.systemDateTime.lastChangedAt: true 
CHANGED_AT as ChangedAt, 
@Consumption.hidden: true 
1 as SingletonID, 
_EmployeeTableAll, 

case when CONFIGDEPRECATIONCODE = 'W' then 2 when CONFIGDEPRECATIONCODE = 'E' then 1 else 3 end as ConfigDeprecationCode_Critlty, 

_ConfignDeprecationCodeText 

}

19.behaviour definition

managed with additional save implementation in class ZBP_I_EMPLOYEETABLE_S1 unique; 
strict; 
with draft;

entry.title: Re: Discrepancy in Amount Calculation D
entry.content:
SAP calculates taxes at the item level, then sums them up at the header. If rounding is applied per item, the total tax may differ slightly from what you'd expect if calculated on the full base amount. This is especially noticeable with GST at 18%, where fractional values (e.g., 1138.68) are rounded inconsistently.

Coming to your issue, not sure, how currently, your system set up is and I presume, it is GST India. Maintain the standard settings for rounding by following the below steps

In OBQ1, maintain the rounding rule under "Control data 1" tab
Specify the rounding rules in ob90
check in your SD pricing procedure, whether routines 16 or 17 is assigned to your tax condition type

For information, Routine 16 will round the tax value per item, whereas, for Routine 17, instead of rounding each itemâ€™s tax and summing, SAP will calculate tax on the total and round once.  So for your issue, it is better to assign Routine 17

Let us take an example of the issue you shared and assume, you set Routine 17 which will calculate as under

  • Total Base: â‚¹6576.00
  • GST @18%: â‚¹1183.68
  • Final Invoice: â‚¹7759.68 (rounded correctly)

Once these changes are carried out, create a new sale order and complete the full cycle. Check how GST flows now.

entry.title: SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
Why this matters: the upcoming changes turn what looked like a technical switch into a strategic decision that can affect your budget, compliance posture, and HCM roadmap. Activations of Business Function for SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA directly influence whether you need additional HCM licenses, which capabilities you can keep on-premise versus in Private Cloud, and how quickly you should plan a move to SuccessFactors for certain functions. Getting ahead of this now helps you avoid unplanned costs or audit exposure, prevents disruption to HR processes tied to payroll, time, and regulatory reporting, and gives you time to align contracts, license product codes, and project timelines. The guidance below distills whatâ€™s changing and the practical steps to stay compliant while keeping your transformation on track.

Starting with SAP S/4HANA 2025, the Business Function for SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANAâ€¯ will be turned on by default. From this release on, there is no compatibility pack for HCM anymore. â€¯This technical change is not reversible. The licensing requirements are applicable when SAP HCM is utilized beyond the scope of the HR Mini Master, in cases where the customer is conducting HCM processes in the system.

For the technical details, please check the KBA 3443536 - SAP S/4HANA Release 2025 will be delivered with active H4S4_1 Business Function - SAP for Me 

Some functionality is not available in S/4HANA Private Cloud; e.g. SAP Learning Solution is available in S/4HANA on-premise, when moving to Private Cloud, the go-to solution is SuccessFactors Learning.

You can see the details of what features are enabled and what are disabled you can check in the following note 3091160 - SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA â€“ General Approach and Strategy - SAP for Me 

A customer using the HCM compatibility pack today in SAP S/4HANA on-premise can receive a prolongation only if they move to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition, via a lift-and-shift (like-for-like) migration that preserves the current release. If the move includes an upgrade to the 2025 release, the H4S4_1 business function will be active by default, and the HCM compatibility pack will no longer be available, so prolongation does not apply.  With the requested change, they would get the prolongation as well in case they directly move to SuccessFactors, which is our strategic intent.

HCM License Materials and Usage Rights 

 

Customers must also license SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA latest the first day after the expiry of the Compatibility Package.

Please contact your account executive to plan the license conversion as soon as possible. 

I hope you found this blog post helpful. If you did, please give it a "like" or share it. Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts and feedback, so feel free to leave a comment. If you have any questions, just drop them in the Q&A section with the tags SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. We'll try to get back to you as soon as we can.


Thanks,

Brought to you by the SAP S/4HANA RIG team.

entry.title: Re: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ App Variants are the EASY way to control App Features
entry.content:
Hi Hilderink, Thanks for your feedback. 

I can see some merit in suggesting a better way to map app variants to LADIs in the technical catalogs via the Adaptation Mode of Launchpad App Manager - at the very least it might be helpful to have a way to select app variants based on the original app id.  You might want to think it over and suggest an idea in the Continuous Influence program for Digital Experience https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/campaign/2279 This would bring it to the attention of other customers for similar needs to start the journey to getting it on the roadmap. 

Re duplicating entries in the business catalog - that should not be necessary and might be a possible cause of your issues?  We would typically envision that different roles would have different business catalogs as business catalogs drive which apps (including app variants) are assigned to which users.

  • Each business catalog can reference one or more entries from the underlying technical catalog.
  • Different business catalogs could have the same SemanticObject-Action pair targeting different app variants. 

E.g.

  • Role Z_BR_XXX_EDIT includes business catalog Z_BC_XXX_EDIT which references the original app
  • Role Z_BR_XXX_DISPLAY includes business catalog Z_BC_XXX_DISPLAY which references the app variant

Re Authorizations versus App Variants - these 2 approaches are intended to be complimentary. They are not a replacement for each other. 

Authorizations control what you are allowed to do. Even if a button is visible, if you are not authorized to perform the underlying action you will get an error. These can often be fine-grained, e.g. you might have access to edit Sales Orders but are restricted to editing Sales Orders of a certain sales order type only. In which case, you still need the edit button to be available.

App Variants control visibility - that covers a whole range of UX changes such as:

  • Showing/placing optional fields - including SAP predefined fields and custom fields
  • Showing/hiding buttons, tabs, cards, etc.
  • Creating public views for filter settings, table settings, chart settings, card settings. 

 App variants improve usability by refining the app for the use case.

Perhaps you could think through those suggestions through and see if that helps you.

P.s. A launchpad plug-in would not be suitable. ... as these are applied asynchronously (so the button could show and then disappear..!) We tend to use those for launchpad features. 

Hope that helps

entry.title: Re: ST-PI Version Compatibility Between SAP Solution Mana...
entry.content:
Hello team,

This is correct, ST-PI and ST/A-PI are the Software Components that contain all the code (Function Modules and Reports) to collect data from Managed Systems. 

Both are installed in SAP Solution Manager and Managed Systems, because we collect data from both sides.

The version is linked to the Netweaver version, so it might be different version comparing Solution Manager and Managed System.

To check latest available version, you can run Transaction ST13, tool RTCCTOOL  which will provide relevant SAP Notes in case an update is required. 

Keeping these Software Components fully updated, will ensure there is no data collection issue due to code bugs. 

Regards,

Luis Salazar

entry.title: Re: Cross data locking
entry.content:
SAP authorization objects like K_CSKA (for cost elements) and K_CCTR (for cost centers) do not evaluate combinations. They check whether a user has access to a cost element or a cost center, but not whether theyâ€™re allowed to use a specific pair.

With some custom validation, you can meet this requirement. Explore BADI_FAGL_POSTING or BADI_K_KKB_AUTHORITY with which you can build logic to block specific combinations like 20321078 + 210020. Maintain the required combination like Cost Element 210020 / Cost Center 20321078 and User ID in TVARVC table. With the above BAdI, whenever user tries to create order or posting, system to check this table and if maintained, allow to proceed; else, throw an error. With this approach, at a later date, for some reasons, if you want to add a new entry or delete the existing entry, users can do on their own and no need for code change.

entry.title: Re: Enhancement or Exits to Campaing PCA1
entry.content:
To make the field GPROZGR mandatory on both the initial and second screen, youâ€™ll need to identify the screen number and field name.

For that, you can go from the transaction screen itself where from the top menu bar, click on System > Status so that it will show the screen number. The other option is via SE51, you can get these details. The correct technical name for GPROZGR is GRPNAME. To find out a related BAdI, go to SE18 and input ES_SAPLCPC1 in the Enhancement Spot field. This will list out all BAdIs

entry.title: Re: which is the difference between country key and repor...
entry.content:
In the context of fiscal representation, it's appropriate to use the fields as follows:

Country Key: This should reflect the parent company's country of registrationâ€”i.e., the country where the legal entity is based. It identifies the origin of the company involved in the transaction.

Reporting Country: This should indicate the country where the fiscal representative is registered and where the invoice will be reported for tax purposes. This is typically the country in which VAT or other indirect taxes are declared.

entry.title: Re: ST-PI Version Compatibility Between SAP Solution Mana...
entry.content:
Hello Rsnit and Luis,

Thanks very much for your input. Iâ€™ve reviewed several SAP sources and found some relevant distinctions.

In one SAP blog, itâ€™s stated that:

â€œIt is highly recommended to keep software component ST-PI at the latest support package level (see SAP Note 539977) in Managed System as well as in the Solution Manager system. [â€¦] The data collector changes provided in higher support packages are downward compatible e.g. a Solution Manager on ST 710 SP 12 can call a data collector in a managed system with ST-PI 2008_1_ SP 13.â€*

This suggests that certain ST-PI functionalities, like data collectors, are designed to be downward compatible.

However, in SAP Note 69455 regarding ST-A/PI, itâ€™s mentioned:

â€œMay occur if the satellite system is on ST-A/PI >=01L but Solution Manager does not yet have the ST-SER 701_2008_2 [â€¦] RTCCTOOL was enhanced [â€¦] but the older Solution Manager release does not yet understand this.â€

This indicates that other functionalities, such as RTCCTOOL integration with EarlyWatch Alert, may not be compatible if Solution Manager is on an older release.

Therefore, it seems there is no general SAP note that guarantees full downward compatibility across all ST-PI and ST-A/PI functionalities. While best practice remains to keep versions aligned, where this isnâ€™t feasible, does SAP officially guarantee downward compatibility when the managed system is on a higher release than Solution Manager?

Best regards,
Silvio

export default function ProductListImage(clientAPI) {

entry.title: Re: Skipping popup messages in VA03 for Sales Order Incom...
entry.content:
SAP Note 1459252 suggests this only as a workaround, not a standard solution. Itâ€™s not part of core functionality, so it should be treated as a last resort.

If the goal is to reduce user frustration without compromising data integrity:

  • First, analyze which fields are causing the incompletion logs.
  • Then, adjust the incompletion procedure to remove non-critical fields.
  • Use BAdIs or user exits to suppress popups for completed orders.
  • Only consider deleting from VBUV if all else fails; and always back up the data first.

entry.title: Re: The Value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in The Context of Business Steering
entry.content:
Hi @thomaselit,

Great feedback and I will try to address it:

Besides the mentioned (and â€œexcludedâ€) components SAP BDC is also introducing new services. Such as:

  1. Curated SaaS Data products
  2. Intelligent Apps
  3. SAP Databricks (for AI/ML) use cases

We are adding business content  - data models, semantics and solutions â€“ intelligent apps (such as Working Capital, People Intelligence and more to come) to tackle the volatility of todays market. We are doing this in true SaaS manner (â€œplug & playâ€), so that our customers donâ€™t have to reinvent the wheel when it comes to data integration, modelling, preserving business rules & semantics from source systems, etc. The platform is fully integrated with our AI services (SAP AI Hub), that will help to introduce new use cases when it comes to supporting the business steering (for example AI agent to provide additional insights about our business performance in the context of overall market performance, AI agent for risk analysis â€“ going towards the prescriptive analytics by providing suggestions, etc). We are also enabling advanced AI/ML use cases with SAP Databricks without the replication (delta share/zero copy) - > allowing (near) real time insights and moreâ€¦

In case you need more support with presenting/selling the SAP BDC offering to your customer(s) please get in touch with our local SAP office to get some additional support (alternatively feel free to send me a message and we can connect you to the right people in your region).

entry.title: Re: ST-PI Version Compatibility Between SAP Solution Mana...
entry.content:
Hello Silvio,

The comment  you refer:

Q14: "Last run of report RTCCTOOL" in EWAlert too old
A14: May occur if the satellite system is on ST-A/PI >=01L but Solution Manager does not yet have the ST-SER 701_2008_2 (both as of December 2008). RTCCTOOL was enhanced as of ST-A/PI 01L to deliver the full recommendations to the EWAlert, but the older Solution Manager release does not yet understand this.
As a workaround run report RTCCTOOL from Tx SE38 and choose Goto->Old RTCCTOOL from the menu. This runs the old tool, which should now also return green status lights for everything that's up to date. The next EWA ( with your current ST-SER) takes this info from the old tool into account.
As a permanent solution, update your Solution Manager to EhP1 (ST 400 SP18, ST-SER 701_2008_2).

It talks about 2008 version which probably referred to SAP Solution Manager 7.0 or 7.1 version. 
There shouldn't be such situation right now, so best practice is to check with RTCCTOOL which is the latest available version to implement on corresponding system. 

Regards,

Luis Salazar

entry.title: Re: I want to display the â€œyear and monthâ€ of the system...
entry.content:
@tsuuuu 

A simple js code in on initialization event of the page can get you that.

Create a script variable of type string called CurrentDate ( can name it as per your choice)

Put the below code in the  on initialization event of the page

var currentDate = new Date(Date.now()); //fetch current date

if(currentDate.getMonth()+1<10) // +1 as js month index at 0
{
	CurrentDate =currentDate.getFullYear().toString()+"/"+ "0"+ (currentDate.getMonth() + 1).toString();
}
	else
		{
			CurrentDate =currentDate.getFullYear().toString()+"/"+ "0"+ (currentDate.getMonth() + 1).toString();
		}

Finally bind the dynamic text with script variable CurrentDate

Output:

 

Hope this helps !!

Nikhil

entry.title: Re: Setting up default Variant in ME28
entry.content:
The Scope of List field in ME28 is not variant-sensitive, meaning it doesn't retain the value from your saved variant when you reopen the transaction. Even if you save a variant with "BEST" selected, ME28 will default back to "ALV" unless additional steps are taken.

One option which you can explore is create a Custom Transaction (ZME28) via SE93 with your saved variant of ME28. In the setup, specify the variant where "BEST" is selected. This way, users launch ZME28 and get the desired Scope of List by default. But this is worth only

  • if ME28 is used daily by multiple users, and everyone has to manually switch the Scope of List to "BEST" each time, thatâ€™s a lot of wasted clicks.
  • If users consistently forget to change the Scope of List, leading to incorrect or incomplete release processing.
  • A custom transaction simplifies onboardingâ€”users just launch ZME28 and get the correct setup instantly.

The other option is to have an user parameter transaction which can be done via SE93 through which you can create a new tcode ZME28_BEST. Select "Transaction with parameters (parameter transaction)". In the transaction field, set ME28. Set default parameters by adding the following:

  • D_SREPOVARI-REPORT = RM06EF00 (the program behind ME28)
  • D_SREPOVARI-VARIANT = your saved variant name (e.g., BEST_SCOPE)

These parameters ensure ME28 loads with your desired variant.

entry.title: Enhanced Tax Calculation in the Upload Customer Open Items App
entry.content:
Starting from SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2508,  a new field, Tax Amount (TAXAMOUNTINTRANSCRCY), has been added to the Header Data section of the upload template for the Upload Customer Open Items app.

Depending on the value in this field, the system calculates taxes differently:

  • If you leave the field empty or set the field value to zero, the system calculates the tax amount automatically based on the tax code you specified during checking and posting.
  • If you enter a tax amount in this field, the system uses the amount you specified manually for checking and posting.
The Tax Amount field is hidden by default in the template. To make it visible, unhide the columns at the end of the Header Data section.
Field Technical NameField Name
TAXAMOUNTINTRANSCRCYTax Amount

Depending on the value in this field, the system calculates taxes differently:
If you leave the field empty or set the field value to zero, the system calculates the tax amount automatically based on the tax code you specified in the Tax Code (2) field during checking and posting.

If you enter a tax amount, the system uses the amount you specified manually for checking and posting.
 
After uploading an open item back to the app, you can view the Tax Amount field in the Details section of the open item details page and edit the field value as needed.
 
 
Note

You cannot enter a tax amount manually at the G/L account item level. When you enter a tax amount for an open item in the header and use different tax codes in its G/L account items, the system automatically distributes the tax amount among the various tax codes during checking and posting.

entry.title: How to use latest QUnit and sinon to test your SAPUI5 applications
entry.content:
Are you a SAPUI5 developer who loves writing unit tests but feels held back by the outdated versions of sinon and qunit bundled with the framework? You're not alone.

For convenience, the SAPUI5 framework ships with its own versions of these popular testing libraries, available directly from the UI5 CDN. The challenge, however, is that these bundled versions are outdated. The SAPUI5 CDN supplies sinon v4 at latest, which is more than 7 years old, while version 21 is already available. As there are no plans to update the version available in the CDN (see https://github.com/UI5/openui5/issues/3204), we developers have to integrate it by ourselves to benefit from sinon's and qunit's latest features. That is some cumbersome work, esp. if every project / developer needs to figure out the 'right' way to do it.

In this post, we'll walk you through a setup that allows you to integrate the latest versions of sinon and qunit into your SAPUI5 project, unlocking its latest features, superior type-safety, and a much-improved developer experience. Let's get started!

There are 2 possibilities to approach this depending on your UI5 version (see feat: Use Test Starter Â· ui5-community/generator-ui5-ts-app)
1. UI5 version >= 1.124: using test starter setup
2. UI5 version < 1.124: using traditional test suite & test page setup

To guide you through the steps, we will use the easy-ui5 generator to generate a TypeScript application (I can strongly recommend this tool). You can install it via the following command (see also generator-easy-ui5 - npm)

npm install -g yo generator-easy-ui5

Additionally, we need to use the middleware ui5-tooling-modules-middleware of the UI5 Tooling ecosystem. This middleware enables you to use NPM package names for AMD-like dependencies. It captures the requests to the path /resources/ and checks whether a dependency or devDependency is included with the identical name as the requested resource. If this is the case, it will serve this dependency from your installed node_modules and return it as a AMD-like dependency. This enables you to easily utilise third-party packages in your UI5 applications.

Using UI5 >= 1.124

We create our new application via the following command:

yo easy-ui5 ts-app

For the sample the namespace com.testing.unit is used. Now, make sure to choose a version greater than or equals 1.124.0. Answer the remaining questions according to your preferences.

Afterwards, add qunit and sinon to devDependencies:

npm install --save-dev sinon @types/sinon qunit @types/qunit

If not already present, add also the latest version of ui5-tooling-modules-middleware  to the devDependencies:

npm install ui5-tooling-modules --save-dev -rte

By using the flag -rte or --register-tooling-extension the module adds its configuration automatically to the default UI5 yaml files. If you want to add it to other specific files, you can mention them after the flag: -rte ui5.yaml,ui5-workspace.yaml. Please make sure that the ui5-coverage.yaml is configured as follows. This UI5 yaml file is used to execute your tests. You must add the middleware ui5-tooling-modules-middleware to the server serving the application. Add this middleware to the section server/customMiddleware as shown below. The only custom configuration option we use, is debug: verbose to get a more detailed logging output in case of errors. Then, we can easily see whether a dependency was added and served or ignored. The transpiling of your TypeScript code must be executed after the middleware as the dependencies could potentially also contain TypeScript code.

...
server:
  customMiddleware:
	- name: ui5-tooling-modules-middleware
      afterMiddleware: compression
      configuration:
        debug: verbose
    - name: ui5-tooling-transpile-middleware
      afterMiddleware: ui5-tooling-modules-middleware
      configuration:
        targetBrowsers: "defaults and supports async-functions"
        debug: true
        transpileDependencies: true
        babelConfig:
          sourceMaps: true
          ignore:
            - "**/*.d.ts"
          presets:
            - - "@babel/preset-env"
              - targets: defaults
            - - transform-ui5
            - "@babel/preset-typescript"
          plugins:
            - istanbul

Now, you get a new test setup using the test starter setup. Instead of the traditional test suite and test pages for unit and integration test setup, you get a testsuite.qunit.ts with central configuration options and for the unit and integration tests a source file (unitTests.qunit.ts / opaTests.qunit.ts) where you just import your test cases. In the testsuite.qunit.ts we can configure the used versions for qunit and sinon. By default, only the versions available in the CDN can be used. Luckily, you can add custom versions to the versions map and consume them via ui5-tooling-modules-middleware. Therefore, you have to add the property versions to the qunit and sinon object and insert your version of the libraries to be used.
Additionally, for qunit you have to define the module itself and the path to the css file so that you get the tests page styled as you are used to. For sinon, you have to define the module and the bridge which helps qunit to communicate with sinon. The value of these properties is the path used to load the source files. They are automatically loaded from the /resources/ path. Therefore, this part must not be contained in the property value. The default bridge from SAPUI5 core can be reused, even with the latest version of sinon. Now, you just have to specify the version. This must be identical to the version number you just maintained in the property versions.

Then, the result shall look like this:

export default {
	name: "QUnit test suite for the UI5 Application: com.testing.unit",
	defaults: {
		page: "ui5://test-resources/com/testing/unit/Test.qunit.html?testsuite={suite}&test={name}",
		qunit: {
			version: "2.24.1",
			versions: {
				"2.24.1": {
					module: "qunit",
					css: "qunit/qunit/qunit.css",
				},
			},
		},
		sinon: {
			version: "21.0.0",
			versions: {
				"21.0.0": {
					module: "sinon",
					bridge: "sap/ui/qunit/sinon-qunit-bridge",
				},
			},
		},
		ui5: {
			language: "EN",
			theme: "sap_horizon",
		},
		coverage: {
			only: "com/testing/unit/",
			never: "test-resources/com/testing/unit/",
		},
		loader: {
			paths: {
				"com/testing/unit": "../",
			},
			map: {
				"*": {
					qunit: null,
					sinon: null,
				},
			},
		},
	},
	tests: {
		"unit/unitTests": {
			title: "Unit tests for com.testing.unit",
		},
		"integration/opaTests": {
			title: "Integration tests for com.testing.unit",
		},
	},
};

Additionally, you have to overwrite SAPUI5's module loader so that qunit and sinon won't be loaded from the CDN. Otherwise, every import of sinon and qunit would be redirected to sap/ui/thirdparty/<sinon/qunit>. Therefore, you have to adapt the property defaults/loader/map/*. In there, set the value null for qunit and sinon. Then, our custom mapping applies and the source files are requested from our own application. The middleware ui5-tooling-modules-middleware will recognise that a local dependency is requested, package it as a SAPUI5 module and return it to the running application.

In short you have to do 3 things:
- Maintain the version to be used
- Add your custom version to the versions map
- Overwrite SAPUI5's default module loader to not load sinon and qunit from the CDN

Now, you can continue with the section Verify your setup.

Using UI5 < 1.124

If you are not able to use the latest version, you have to rely on the traditional suite and test page setup like we UI5 developers are used to. Nevertheless, the same as above is possible with this approach.

We create our new application via the following command:

yo easy-ui5 ts-app

For the sample the namespace com.testing.unit is used. Now make sure to choose a version lower than 1.124.0. Answer the remaining questions according to your preferences.

Afterwards, add qunit and sinon to devDependencies:

npm install --save-dev sinon @types/sinon qunit @types/qunit

If not already present, add also the latest version of ui5-tooling-modules-middleware to the devDependencies:

npm install ui5-tooling-modules --save-dev -rte

By using the flag -rte or --register-tooling-extension the module adds its configuration automatically to the default UI5 yaml files. If you want to add it to other specific files, you can mention them after the flag: -rte ui5.yaml,ui5-workspace.yaml. Please make sure that the ui5-coverage.yaml is configured as described above:

...
server:
  customMiddleware:
	- name: ui5-tooling-modules-middleware
      afterMiddleware: compression
      configuration:
        debug: verbose
    - name: ui5-tooling-transpile-middleware
      afterMiddleware: ui5-tooling-modules-middleware
      configuration:
        targetBrowsers: "defaults and supports async-functions"
        debug: true
        transpileDependencies: true
        babelConfig:
          sourceMaps: true
          ignore:
            - "**/*.d.ts"
          presets:
            - - "@babel/preset-env"
              - targets: defaults
            - - transform-ui5
            - "@babel/preset-typescript"
          plugins:
            - istanbul

Now, please adapt your test/unit/unitTests.qunit.html to overwrite SAP's default module loader and ensure that sinon and qunit are loaded form the local resources.

<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>Applicationportal - Unit Tests</title>
    <meta charset="utf-8" />

    <script
      id="sap-ui-bootstrap"
      src="/resources/sap-ui-core.js"
      data-sap-ui-resourceroots='{
		  "aa.foerdermittelportal.applicationportal.ui": "../../"
	  }'
      data-sap-ui-async="false"
    ></script>

    <!-- Load sinon and qunit before stylesheet to ensure that they are loaded when test execution starts by requiring unitTests.qunit.js -->
    <script src="/resources/sinon.js"></script>
    <script src="/resources/qunit.js"></script>
    <!-- Overwrite default mapping, otherwise every import of sinon and qunit is redirected to sap/ui/thirdparty/<sinon/qunit> by ui5loader -->
    <script>
      sap.ui.loader.config({
        map: {
          "*": {
            qunit: null,
            sinon: null,
          },
        },
      });
    </script>

    <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="/resources/qunit/qunit/qunit.css" />

    <script src="unitTests.qunit.js"></script>
  </head>
  <body>
    <div id="qunit"></div>
    <div id="qunit-fixture"></div>
  </body>
</html>

Now, you can continue with the section Verify your setup.

Verify your setup

Now, we will add a unit test to showcase that the latest version of sinon is used. Therefore, we first add a new method to the Main.controller.ts:

import MessageBox from "sap/m/MessageBox";
import BaseController from "./BaseController";
import JSONModel from "sap/ui/model/json/JSONModel";

/**
 *  com.testing.unit.controller
 */
export default class Main extends BaseController {
	public sayHello(): void {
		MessageBox.show("Hello World!");
	}

	public getGreeting(): string {
		const model = this.getModel("greeting") as JSONModel;

		return model.getProperty("/greeting") as string;
	}
}

To test the new method, add the following test, to your webapp/test/unit/controller/Main.qunit.ts:

import Main from "com/testing/unit/controller/Main.controller";
import JSONModel from "sap/ui/model/json/JSONModel";
import * as sinon from "sinon";

type TestContext = {
	controller: Main;
	stubbedJSONModel: sinon.SinonStubbedInstance<JSONModel>;
};

QUnit.module("Sample Main controller test", {
	beforeEach(this: TestContext) {
		this.stubbedJSONModel = sinon.createStubInstance(JSONModel);
		this.controller = new Main("test");
	},

	afterEach(this: TestContext) {
		sinon.restore();
	},
});

QUnit.test("sinon v21 is used", function (this: TestContext, assert) {
	const getModelStub = sinon.stub(this.controller, "getModel");
	getModelStub.withArgs("greeting").returns(this.stubbedJSONModel);

	this.stubbedJSONModel.getProperty.returns("Hello from sinon v21!");

	this.controller.getGreeting();

	assert.strictEqual(this.controller.getGreeting(), "Hello from sinon v21!");

	// -expect-error sinon fakeXMLHttpRequest is removed with sinon v20
	assert.strictEqual(undefined, sinon.fakeXMLHttpRequest);
});

If you get an error regarding the import of sinon, adapt your tsconfig.json to allow allowSyntheticDefaultImports:

{
	compilerOptions: {
		...
		"allowSyntheticDefaultImports": true,
		...
	}
}

In short, we did 2 things:
- Imported sinon to be able to write assertions,
- Added the tests which verifies that we are using the latest version of sinon by ensuring that methods which are no longer available in v21 are undefined.

Now you can start your application using the ui5-coverage.yaml:

npm run start-coverage

Open the test page in your browser and open also the network tab of your developer tools:

  • If you are using UI5 >= 1.124: http://localhost:8080/test/Test.qunit.html?testsuite=test-resources/com/testing/unit/testsuite.qunit&test=unit/unitTests 
  • If you are using UI5 < 1.124: http://localhost:8080/test/unit/unitTests.qunit.html 

Once the tests are executed, you can verify the sources returned for sinon and qunit. You will see, that the configured versions are loaded and used:

And the same for qunit:

 And also in your server's logs:

The first warning regarding the package sinon can be ignored (see orange marked section in the logs). sinon is only used for our tests and therefore included as a devDependency. Therefore, the warning will arise but in a deployed we won't need this dependency. This means we are fine with the dynamic inclusion of sinon into our bundle (see red marked section in the logs).

Conclusion

By moving away from the default bundled libraries and integrating your own dependencies, you've now unlocked the full potential of modern testing in your SAPUI5 application. To make your journey as smooth as possible, the complete sample project is available on GitHub: ui5-unit-testing-latest-qunit-sinon  
Happy testing!
If you have any questions or found this guide helpful, feel free to leave a comment below. If you are interested in the setup of the coverage reporting for UI5 applications, we may cover this in a part 2 in the future.

entry.title: SAC 2025 Q3 QRC Optimized Story API - Is there a change in DataSource.getMeasures() behavior?
entry.content:
Hello, I am using SAC Analytics Cloud and utilize scripts to enhance the functionality of optimized stories.  Last week we received latest quarterly update (2025 Q3 QRC, version 2025.14.8).  After the update, I noticed the behavior of DataSource.getMeasures() has changed. 

The API Reference says this method "Returns all measures of the data source" and this was exactly the behavior before.  Now it only returns the first 200 measures, just like the default behavior of DataSource.getMembers().  This causes problem for my existing stories because our queries usually contain 200+ measures (model-defined measures + story calculations). 
To make it worse, now the story calculations are indexed after model-defined measures (before the update: calculations first), so calculations are almost never included in getMeasures() method.

Is this an intended change?  Shall I modify the scripts in stories now, or wait for a fix in next versions? Thanks.

entry.title: Elevate Your Promotion Strategy: Baseline Management with SAP Revenue Growth Management
entry.content:
1. The Blind Spot: How Baseline Data Impacts KAM Success

For Key Account Managers, managing promotional success often starts with understanding the sales baseline â€” the steady sales volume without promotions. Without a clear baseline, measuring promotional lift and trade spend ROI can feel like groping around looking for a lightswitch in the dark. Manual data handling, inconsistent baselines across systems, and lack of flexibility to reflect market changes can turn promotion planning into a high-stakes gamble.

 

2. SAP Revenue Growth Management: A Foundation for Data-Driven Revenue Planning

SAP Revenue Growth Management (RGM) addresses the challenges above. Designed for consumer products companies, our solution empowers KAMs with intuitive, integrated, and flexible baseline management tools â€” whether you manage key accounts at a major corporation or lead revenue growth at a midsize company.

For more information on our current capabilities, see An Overview of SAP Revenue Growth Management.

 

3. Baseline in Action: Three Essentials Shaping Smarter Account Planning

Baseline isnâ€™t just a numberâ€”itâ€™s the foundation for every strategic decision a KAM makes. Among the many strengths of SAP Revenue Growth Management, the Baseline feature stands out as the backbone. Hereâ€™s how its three core strengths put you in control:

3.1. Baseline Maintenance via Excelâ€” Seamlessly Fits KAM Workflow

For teams accustomed to spreadsheets, SAP Revenue Growth Management meets you where you are.

  • Matching Existing Processes

Many KAMs at small and medium enterprises traditionally manage revenue and baseline data in Excel. SAP Revenue Growth Management respects this workflow by enabling KAMs to download Excel templates, fill in baseline volumes offline, and then upload the completed files back into the system.

  • Minimal Training, Maximum Adoption

KAMs can leverage familiar spreadsheet skills to manage baselines without learning new systems, accelerating adoption and ensuring data quality.

 

This approach is especially effective for small-to-medium companies whose teams may not have supply chain and demand planning tools like SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) to forecast and manage sell-in baselines, or other tools that produce consumption-based demand forecasts from syndicated sell-out data. The baseline upload and building blocks in SAP Revenue Growth Management allow KAMs to efficiently devise and handle a forecasted sell-in baseline without waiting for centralized teams.

 

3.2. Integrating with External Demand Planning System via Open API â€” Tailored for Large Enterprises

Ideal for larger consumer products companies with centralized demand planning systems and tools.

  • Unified Baseline Integration Across Multiple Sources and Systems

In large companies, a baseline forecast can come from a demand planning tool, such as SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) to forecast sell-in baselines, or a consumption-based forecast from historical sell-out data â€“ with data suitably transformed to utilize the Baseline Volume API of SAP Revenue Growth Management. This approach ensures that baseline data stays current and aligned across systems by week by SKU, significantly reducing manual workload while meeting customers where they are, regardless of the baseline source.

  • Support Role-Based Access and Governance

Planned as a future enhancement, this feature will allow demand planners to centrally edit baselines while KAMs view baselines and work with given numbers to plan promotions and boost revenue. Such organizations can maintain clear data ownership and restrict baseline editing to authorized roles (e.g., demand planners), aligning well with corporate compliance while freeing KAMs to focus on customer strategy.

 

This integration empowers demand planning teams to stay agile in fast-changing markets, while ensuring adherence to corporate data governance.

 

3.3. Baseline Building Blocks: Adapt to Market Realities with Agility

For large enterprises leveraging API integrations, baseline updates are typically centralized with demand planners. Meanwhile, for growing companies, when Excel canâ€™t keep pace with change, the ability for KAMâ€™s to use their account knowledge to adjust and tweak baselines on the fly is necessary.

  • Configurable Baseline Building Blocks for Market Drivers

Adjustment factors like retailers' store openings, renovations, and seasonality can influence sales baseline independently of promotions. In the future, baseline building blocks will become configurable through central configuration managed by admins. Companies will be able to define these market drivers based on their business models and governance requirements. This empowers KAMs to apply tailored, business-driven adjustments at flexible time granularitiesâ€”weekly, monthly, or quarterly viewsâ€”ensuring agile baseline management aligned with real market conditions within SAP Revenue Growth Management.

  • Visual Editing by Product Category and Time Period

KAMs can quickly update baselines for specific product categories and time periods without re-uploading entire datasetsâ€”changes are automatically and reasonably distributed to daily levels, reflecting real business scenarios where promotions are typically planned daily.

 

This feature bridges the gap between static data and fluid market conditions, equipping KAMs to respond promptly with minimal overhead.

 

4. Co-Innovation: Put Your Baseline to Work

Baseline management lays the groundwork for smarter account planning and precise promotion ROI. In SAP Revenue Growth Managementâ€™s embedded analytics feature, the volume and revenue dashboards identify baseline and uplift, providing reporting and visualization of baseline versus uplift.

To stay ahead in a dynamic market, your insights and feedback are invaluable.

If you face challenges such as:

  • Needing more flexible, in-application baseline editing capabilities
  • Wanting streamlined workflows for baseline adjustment and governance
  • Handling the impacts of baseline changes on promotions

Join our co-innovation program to influence planned enhancements, including:

  • In-app baseline editing for real-time updates without Excel
  • Centralized baseline configuration and role-based access controls
  • Enhanced handling of baseline changes and the effects on promotions

Whether you represent a growing company or a global enterprise, your participation will help us enhance the Baseline in SAP Revenue Growth Management. Contact RGM_Engage@sap.com to collaborate and build the next generation of baseline and account planning efficiencies.

More Information

Documentation on SAP Help Portal

Topic Page for SAP Revenue Growth Management

  • Unlocking Trade Spend Control Efficiency with Funds Management in SAP Revenue Growth Management
  • Decoding Promotional Success: Embedded Analytics in SAP Revenue Growth Management
  • Introducing Calendar View in SAP Revenue Growth Management: A Visual Leap for Strategic Planning
  • Consolidating Customer Planning: Unleash Growth with SAP Revenue Growth Managementâ€™s Account Plan
  • Elevate Your Promotion Strategy: Baseline Management with SAP Revenue Growth Management

entry.title: Re: A Leap Forward in Encryption: TLS 1.3 Support in S/4HANA
entry.content:
IMHO the following SAP note is also relevant - would you mind adding it?

3532801 - Support for TLS 1.3 -- Downport for SAP AS ABAP Kernel
https://me.sap.com/notes/3532801

entry.title: Re: Access CDS Objects Exposed as SQL Services Using Microsoft SQL Server
entry.content:
Hi Roberto,
Unfortunately the connection string parameter DecFloatSqlType=WVarchar requires a ABAP Basis version 9.14(Cloud) or 8.16(OnPrem) or higher. On lower backend versions the driver will ignore this parameter and continue to the use the driver specific ODBC type SQL_DECFLOAT for decimal floating point numbers. Your SAP basis version is 7.57.

In any case those decimal floating point numbers present a problem for MicroSoft applications like Excel or MS SQL since they do not support a numeric type with the same value range. DecFloatSqlType=WVarchar is also just a workaround to avoid the driver specific type and in this case the numbers are retrieved as strings. Currently only HANA and DB2 have native support for decimal floating point types and map those types correctly in their federation features.

Casting to DOUBLE is possible but not recommended because you get exactly the rounding problems you want to avoid by using a decimal floating point type. For currency values this may not be suitable. So if you want to add explicit casts for currency values it may be better to cast to a fixed point decimal type.
Regards
                   Frank

SQL> select cast (1.05 as double) DOUB, CAST(1.05 AS DECIMAL) D34N, CAST(1.05 AS DECIMAL(10,2) ) DEC102 from SYS.DUMMY
+----------------------------------------+-------------------------------------------+-------------+

| DOUB | D34N | DEC102 |

+----------------------------------------+-------------------------------------------+-------------+

| 1.0500000000000000444089209850063 | 1.05 | 1.05 |
+----------------------------------------+-------------------------------------------+-------------+
